responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: GitHub API token disclosure via job config.xml
    analysis: |
      The plugin stores GitHub API tokens as plain text in the job `config.xml` file.
      Any user with access to the Jenkins controller filesystem, or who can read arbitrary job configurations,
      can retrieve these tokens.
      There is no indication that the plugin offers any alternative storage mechanism.
    cwe: CWE-922
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/github_branch_source/AbstractGitHubSCMSource.java
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/github_branch_source/GitHubSCMNavigator.java
    classification: very promising
  - headline: Unvalidated Regex in Repository Name Filter
    analysis: |
      The `GitHubSCMNavigator` class allows users to specify a regular expression to filter
      repositories during source discovery. The provided regex string is not validated
      for potentially harmful patterns before compilation. A malicious user could provide
      a crafted regex that takes an excessive amount of time to evaluate, potentially
      leading to a denial of service.
    cwe: CWE-1333
    function_names:
      - setPattern
    filenames:
      - src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/github_branch_source/GitHubSCMNavigator.java
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: GitHub API token disclosure via job config.xml
leads.analysis:
The plugin stores GitHub API tokens as plain text in the job config.xml file.
Any user with access to the Jenkins controller filesystem, or who can read arbitrary job configurations,
can retrieve these tokens.
There is no indication that the plugin offers any alternative storage mechanism.

leads.headline: Unvalidated Regex in Repository Name Filter
leads.analysis:
The GitHubSCMNavigator class allows users to specify a regular expression to filter
repositories during source discovery. The provided regex string is not validated
for potentially harmful patterns before compilation. A malicious user could provide
a crafted regex that takes an excessive amount of time to evaluate, potentially
leading to a denial of service.
